intro: Temnocydia carajura, commonly known as the Brazilian spurge, is a flowering plant native to the Atlantic Forest of Brazil. It belongs to the Euphorbiaceae family, which is characterized by its unique floral structures and often milky sap. The plant typically grows as a shrub, reaching heights of up to 1.5 meters, with lance-shaped leaves and yellow-orange flowers that are clustered in cyathia. It thrives in tropical and subtropical climates, often found in moist, well-drained soils. Due to habitat loss, it is considered a vulnerable species, highlighting the need for conservation efforts in its native range.
